lines.text: If God still lives, my marriage will be bloodier than Helen's.
This truth stands firm... the wise will fly from war, but if war comes, to die well is to win the victor's crown.

[to Hecuba]
I know that I am mad, but mother dearest, now, for this one time, I do not rave.

[to Hecuba about the ordered death of Astyanax]
A herald who must bring such orders should be a man who feels no pity and no shame either... not like me.

[to Helen]
Never make gods out fools to whitewash your own evil.

[to Menelaus]
Am I allowed to speak against the charge? To show you that if I die that I shall die most wronged and innocent?
I have come to kill you, not to argue with you.

[ironically]
Oh, hear her. She must not die unheard.
[last lines]
Trembling body... old weak limbs... you must carry me on to the new day of slavery.
Count no one happy, however fortunate, before he dies.
I think those that are gone care little how they are buried. It is we, the living, our vanity.

[rides up and dismounts; he walks slowly forward and stops some distance from Andromache]
Wife of the noblest man that was in Troy... O wife of Hector, do not hate me. Against my will I come to tell you...
[Andromache looks at him; he continues haltingly]
The people and the kings have all resolved -...
What is it? Evil follows words like those.
This child they order - -
[he can't finish the phrase - he looks away, then through clenched teeth]
Oh, how can I say it...

[presses her son against her]
Not that he does not go with me to the same master -...
No man in Greece shall ever be his master.

[stares at Talthybius, perplexed]
But - - leave him here - - all that is left of Troy?
I don't know how to tell you. What is bad words can't make better -...

[hoping against hope]
I feel you kind. But you have not good news.

[long pause, then he screams out]
Your child must die! There, now you know the whole, bad as it is!
[silence. Then slowly, as if from the marrow of her bones, the scream comes - - wild, scaringly, rising from the dark roots of sound beyond words]

[when some of the women try to help her up]
Let me be. Kindness unwanted is unkindness.

[to Hecuba]
Your dead Polyxena you weep for? What does she know of pain like mine? The living must have hope. Not I, not any more.

[talking about Helen]
No matter what they said, Helen will get back home alive.
And she knows it.
They need her for the victory parade. A symbol of Greek strength.
A bloody trophy.
Who needs her for a trophy? There's all that gold.

[ironically]
The Greeks don't go to war for gold. They find a cause. That's what Helen is - a cause!

[on learning of Astyanax's fate]
O Greeks, you have found ways to torture that are not Greek!
This is no longer Troy. And we are not the lords of Troy. Endure.

[to Cassandra]
Your sufferings, my child, have never taught you wisdom.

[he's told Hecuba that Cassadra is to be Agammemnon's prize and concubine]
A king's bed is not so bad.
